Messages API documentation¶

System control messages¶

class thorpy.message.systemcontrol.MGMSG_HUB_GET_BAYUSED(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

See MGMSG_HUB_REQ_BAYUSED.

class thorpy.message.systemcontrol.MGMSG_HUB_REQ_BAYUSED(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Sent to determine which bay a specific T-Cube is fitted.

class thorpy.message.systemcontrol.MGMSG_HW_DISCONNECT(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Sent by the hardware unit or host when either wants to disconnect from the Ethernet/USB bus.

class thorpy.message.systemcontrol.MGMSG_HW_GET_INFO(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

See MGMSG_HW_REQ_INFO.

Parameters

  • serial_number (int) – unique 8-digit serial number

  • model_number – alphanumeric model number

  • type (int) – hardware type (not really documented)

  • firmware_version (bytes) –

    firmware version

    • byte 0 = minor revision number

    • byte 1 = interim revision number

    • byte 2 = major revision number

    • byte 3 = unused

  • notes (string) – arbitrary alphanumeric information string (48 bytes)

  • empty_space (bytes) – ironically, not an empty space. Contain undocumented information which helps identifying the connected stage. See stage_name_from_get_hw_info() for the reversed engineered algorithm.

  • hw_version (int) – the hardware version number

  • mod_state (int) – the modification state of the hardware

  • nchs (int) – number of channels

Type

model_number: string

class thorpy.message.systemcontrol.MGMSG_HW_REQ_INFO(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Sent to request hardware information from the controller.

class thorpy.message.systemcontrol.MGMSG_HW_RESPONSE(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Sent by the controllers to notify APT Server of some event that requires user intervention, usually some fault or error condition that needs to be handled before normal operation can resume. The message transmits the fault code as a numerical value – see Return Codes.

class thorpy.message.systemcontrol.MGMSG_HW_RICHRESPONSE(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Similarly to MGMSG_HW_RESPONSE, this message is sent by the controllers to notify APT Server of some event that requires user intervention, usually some fault or error condition that needs to be handled before normal operation can resume. However unlike MGMSG_HW_RESPONSE, this message also transmits a printable text string. Upon receiving the message, APT Server displays both the numerical value and the text information, which is useful in finding the cause of the problem.

Parameters

  • msg_ident (int) – If the message is sent in response to an APT message, these bytes show the APT message number that evoked the message. Most often though the message is transmitted as a result of some unexpected fault condition, in which case these bytes are 0x00, 0x00

  • code (int) – This is an internal Thorlabs specific code that specifies the condition that has caused the message (see Return Codes).

  • notes (string) – This is a zero-terminated printable (ascii) text string that contains the textual information about the condition that has occurred. For example: “Hardware Time Out Error”.

class thorpy.message.systemcontrol.MGMSG_HW_START_UPDATEMSGS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Sent to start status updates from the embedded controller. Status update messages contain information about the position and status of the controller (for example limit switch status, motion indication, etc). The messages will be sent by the controller periodically until it receives a MGMSG_HW_STOP_UPDATEMSGS command. In applications where spontaneous messages (i.e. messages which are not received as a response to a specific command) must be avoided the same information can also be obtained by using the relevant MGMSG_MOT_GET_STATUSUPDATE or MGMSG_MOT_GET_DCSTATUSUPDATE message.

class thorpy.message.systemcontrol.MGMSG_HW_STOP_UPDATEMSGS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Sent to stop status updates from the controller – usually called by a client application when it is shutting down, to instruct the controller to turn off status updates to prevent USB buffer overflows on the PC.

class thorpy.message.systemcontrol.MGMSG_MOD_SET_DIGOUTPUTS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

The CONTROL IO connector on the rear panel of the unit exposes a number of digital outputs. The number of outputs available depends on the type of unit. This message is used to configure these digital outputs.

Parameters

class thorpy.message.systemcontrol.MGMSG_RACK_REQ_DIGOUTPUTS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

See MGMSG_RACK_SET_DIGOUTPUTS.

class thorpy.message.systemcontrol.MGMSG_RACK_REQ_STATUSBITS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

This method is applicable only to the MMR modular rack, and 2- and 3-channel card slot type controllers such as the BSC103 and BPC202.

The USER IO connector on the rear panel of these units exposes a number of digital inputs. This function returns a number of status flags pertaining to the status of the inputs on the rack modules, or the motherboard of the controller unit hosting the single channel controller card. These flags are returned in a single 32 bit integer parameter and can provide additional useful status information for client application development. The individual bits (flags) of the 32 bit integer value correspond to digital output state.

Parameters

status_bits (int) –

The status bits for the associated controller channel.

  • bit 1: Digital output 1 state (1 - logic high, 0 - logic low).

  • bit 2: Digital output 1 state (1 - logic high, 0 - logic low).

  • bit 3: Digital output 1 state (1 - logic high, 0 - logic low).

  • bit 4: Digital output 1 state (1 - logic high, 0 - logic low).

class thorpy.message.systemcontrol.MGMSG_RACK_SET_DIGOUTPUTS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

This method is applicable only to the MMR rack modules, and 2- and 3-channel card slot type controllers such as the BSC103 and BPC202.

The USER IO connector on the rear panel of these units exposes a number of digital outputs. These functions set and return the status of the outputs on the rack modules, or the motherboard of the controller unit hosting the single channel controller card. These flags are returned in a single 32 bit integer parameter and can provide additional useful status information for client application development. The individual bits (flags) of the 32 bit integer value are described below.

Motor control messages¶

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_HW_NO_FLASH_PROGRAMMING(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

This message is sent on start up to notify the controller of the source and destination addresses. A client application must send this message as part of its initialization process.

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_HW_YES_FLASH_PROGRAMMING(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

This message is sent by the server on start up, however, it is a deprecated message (i.e. has no function) and can be ignored.

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_ACK_DCSTATUSUPDATE(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Only Applicable If Using USB COMMS. Does not apply to RS-232 COMMS

If using the USB port, this message called “server alive” must be sent by the server to the controller at least once a second or the controller will stop responding after ~50 commands. The controller keeps track of the number of “status update” type of messages (e.g.move complete message) and it if has sent 50 of these without the server sending a “server alive” message, it will stop sending any more “status update” messages. This function is used by the controller to check that the PC/Server has not crashed or switched off. There is no response.

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_GET_ADCINPUTS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

See MGMSG_MOT_REQ_ADCINPUTS.

Parameters

  • chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • adc_input1 – The voltage state of the analog input pin, in the range 0 to 32768, which corresponds to zero to 5 V.

  • adc_input2 (int) – Not used.

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_GET_BOWINDEX(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

See MGMSG_MOT_SET_BOWINDEX.

Parameters

  • chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • bow_index (int) – This parameter is used to set the profile mode to either Trapezoidal or S-curve. A Bow Index of ‘0’ selects a trapezoidal profile. An index value of ‘1’ to ‘18’ selects an S- curve profile.

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_GET_JOGPARAMS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

See MGMSG_MOT_SET_JOGPARAMS.

Parameters

  • chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • jog_mode (int) – continuous (0x01) or single step (0x02) jogging.

  • jog_step_size (int) – The jog step size. Conversion should be done as in GenericStage.

  • jog_min_velocity (int) – The minimum (start) velocity. Conversion should be done as in GenericStage.

  • jog_acceleration (int) – The acceleration. Conversion should be done as in GenericStage.

  • jog_max_velocity (int) – The maxium (final) velocity. Conversion should be done as in GenericStage.

  • jog_stop_mode (int) – abrupt stop (0x01) or profiled stop (0x02).

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_GET_LIMSWITCHPARAMS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

See MGMSG_MOT_SET_LIMSWITCHPARAMS.

Parameters

  • chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • cw_hard_limit (int) –

    The operation of the Clockwise hardware limit switch when contact is made. If value is OR’d with 0x80, then swap cw_hard_limit and ccw_hard_limit.

    Values:

    • 0x01: Ignore switch or switch not present.

    • 0x02: Switch makes on contact.

    • 0x03: Switch breaks on contact.

    • 0x04: Switch makes on contact - only used for homes (e.g. limit switched rotation stages).

    • 0x05: Switch breaks on contact - only used for homes (e.g. limit switched rotations stages).

    • 0x06 For PMD based brushless servo controllers only - uses index mark for homing.

  • ccw_hard_limit (int) – The operation of the Counter Clockwise hardware limit switch when contact is made.

  • cw_soft_limit (int) – Clockwise software limit in position steps. Not applicable to TDC001.

  • ccw_soft_limit (int) – Counter Clockwise software limit in position steps. Not applicable to TDC001.

  • software_limit_mode (int) – Software limit switch mode

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_MOVE_ABSOLUTE_long(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_MOVE_ABSOLUTE_short(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

This command can be used to start a absolute move on the specified motor channel. The absolute move position used for the move will be the parameter sent previously by a MGMSG_MOT_SET_MOVEABSPARAMS command.

Parameters

chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_MOVE_COMPLETED(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Sent by the controller upon completion of a relative or absolute move sequence.

The format of this message is the same as the one of MGMSG_MOT_GET_STATUSUPDATE or MGMSG_MOT_GET_DCSTATUSUPDATE, therefore, only common fields are exported.

Parameters

  • chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • position (int) – The position encoder count. Conversion should be done as in GenericStage.

  • status_bits (int) –

    OR’d value of the following bits:

    • 0x00000001: forward hardware limit switch is active

    • 0x00000002: reverse hardware limit switch is active

    • 0x00000010: in motion, moving forward

    • 0x00000020: in motion, moving reverse

    • 0x00000040: in motion, jogging forward

    • 0x00000080: in motion, jogging reverse

    • 0x00000200: in motion, homing

    • 0x00000400: homed (homing has been completed)

    • 0x00001000: tracking

    • 0x00002000: settled

    • 0x00004000: motion error (excessive position error)

    • 0x01000000: motor current limit reached

    • 0x80000000: channel is enabled

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_MOVE_HOME(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Sent to start a home move sequence on the specified motor channel (in accordance with the home parameters above).

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_MOVE_STOP(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Sent to stop any type of motor move (relative, absolute, homing or move at velocity) on the specified motor channel.

Parameters

  • chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • stop_mode (int) – stop mode (0x01: immediately, 0x02: controlled (profiled) manner)

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_MOVE_STOPPED(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Upon completion of the stop move, the controller sends this message.

The format of this message is the same as the one of MGMSG_MOT_GET_STATUSUPDATE or MGMSG_MOT_GET_DCSTATUSUPDATE, therefore, only common fields are exported.

Parameters

  • chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • position (int) – The position encoder count. Conversion should be done as in GenericStage.

  • status_bits (int) –

    OR’d value of the following bits:

    • 0x00000001: forward hardware limit switch is active

    • 0x00000002: reverse hardware limit switch is active

    • 0x00000010: in motion, moving forward

    • 0x00000020: in motion, moving reverse

    • 0x00000040: in motion, jogging forward

    • 0x00000080: in motion, jogging reverse

    • 0x00000200: in motion, homing

    • 0x00000400: homed (homing has been completed)

    • 0x00001000: tracking

    • 0x00002000: settled

    • 0x00004000: motion error (excessive position error)

    • 0x01000000: motor current limit reached

    • 0x80000000: channel is enabled

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_MOVE_VELOCITY(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

This command can be used to start a move on the specified motor channel. When this method is called, the motor will move continuously in the specified direction, using the velocity parameters set in the MGMSG_MOT_SET_MOVEVELPARAMS command until either a stop command (either StopImmediate or StopProfiled) is called, or a limit switch is reached.

Parameters

  • chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • direction (int) – move direction (0x01=forward, 0x02=reverse)

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_REQ_ADCINPUTS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

This message reads the voltage applied to the analog input on the rear panel CONTROL IO connector, and returns a value in the ADCInput1 parameter. The returned value is in the range 0 to 32768, which corresponds to zero to 5 V. Note. The ADCInput2 parameter is not used at this time. In this way, a 0 to 5V signal generated by a client system could be read in by calling this method and monitored by a custom client application. When the signal reaches a specified value, the application could instigate further actions, such as a motor move.

Parameters

chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_REQ_AVMODES(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

See MGMSG_MOT_SET_AVMODES.

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_RESUME_ENDOFMOVEMSGS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Sent to resume all unsolicited end of move messages and error messages returned by the controller, i.e.

MGMSG_MOT_MOVE_STOPPED MGMSG_MOT_MOVE_COMPLETED MGMSG_MOT_MOVE_HOMED

This is the default state when the controller is powered up.

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_AVMODES(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

The LED on the control keypad can be configured to indicate certain driver states. All modes are enabled by default. However, it is recognised that in a light sensitive environment, stray light from the LED could be undesirable. Therefore it is possible to enable selectively, one or all of the LED indicator modes described below by setting the appropriate value in the Mode Bits parameter.

  • bow_index (int) – This parameter is used to set the profile mode to either Trapezoidal or S-curve. A Bow Index of ‘0’ selects a trapezoidal profile. An index value of ‘1’ to ‘18’ selects an S- curve profile.

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_ENCCOUNTER(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Similarly to the MGMSG_MOT_SET_POSCOUNTER message described previously, this message is used to set the encoder count in the controller and is only applicable to stages and actuators fitted with an encoder. In general, this command is not normally used. Instead, the stage is homed immediately after power-up (at this stage the position is unknown as the stage is free to move when the power is off); and after the homing process is completed the position counter is automatically updated to show the actual position. From this point onwards the encoder counter always shows the actual absolute position.

Parameters

  • chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • encoder_count (int) – The new value of the encoder counter.

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_GENMOVEPARAMS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Parameters

  • chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • backlash_distance (int) – The value of the backlash distance. Conversion should be done as in GenericStage.

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_HOMEPARAMS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Used to set the home parameters for the specified motor channel. These parameters are stage specific and for the MLS203 stage implementation the only parameter that can be changed is the homing velocity.

Parameters

  • chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • home_direction (int) – Ignored in current implementation (0x01=forward, 0x02=reverse)

  • limit_switch (int) – Ignored in current implementation

  • home_velocity (int) – The homing velocity. Conversion should be done as in GenericStage.

  • offset_distance (int) – Not used in current implementation. Conversion should be done as in GenericStage.

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_JOGPARAMS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Used to set the velocity jog parameters for the specified motor channel, For DC servo controllers, values set in encoder counts. For stepper motor controllers the values is set in microsteps.

Parameters

  • chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • jog_mode (int) – continuous (0x01) or single step (0x02) jogging.

  • jog_step_size (int) – The jog step size. Conversion should be done as in GenericStage.

  • jog_min_velocity (int) – The minimum (start) velocity. Conversion should be done as in GenericStage.

  • jog_acceleration (int) – The acceleration. Conversion should be done as in GenericStage.

  • jog_max_velocity (int) – The maxium (final) velocity. Conversion should be done as in GenericStage.

  • jog_stop_mode (int) – abrupt stop (0x01) or profiled stop (0x02).

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_LIMSWITCHPARAMS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Used to set the limit switch parameters for the specified motor channel.

These functions are not applicable to BBD10x units

Parameters

  • chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • cw_hard_limit (int) –

    The operation of the Clockwise hardware limit switch when contact is made. If value is OR’d with 0x80, then swap cw_hard_limit and ccw_hard_limit.

    Values:

    • 0x01: Ignore switch or switch not present.

    • 0x02: Switch makes on contact.

    • 0x03: Switch breaks on contact.

    • 0x04: Switch makes on contact - only used for homes (e.g. limit switched rotation stages).

    • 0x05: Switch breaks on contact - only used for homes (e.g. limit switched rotations stages).

    • 0x06 For PMD based brushless servo controllers only - uses index mark for homing.

  • ccw_hard_limit (int) – The operation of the Counter Clockwise hardware limit switch when contact is made.

  • cw_soft_limit (int) – Clockwise software limit in position steps. Not applicable to TDC001.

  • ccw_soft_limit (int) – Counter Clockwise software limit in position steps. Not applicable to TDC001.

  • software_limit_mode (int) – Software limit switch mode

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_MOVEABSPARAMS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Used to set the absolute move parameters for the specified motor channel. The only significant parameter at this time is the absolute move position itself. This gets stored by the controller and is used the next time an absolute move is initiated.

  • absolute_position (int) – The absolute position to move. Conversion should be done as in GenericStage.

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_PMDCURRENTLOOPPARAMS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Used to set the current control loop parameters for the specified motor channel. The motion processors within the BBD series controllers use digital current control as a technique to control the current through each phase winding of the motors. In this way, response times are improved and motor efficiency is increased. This is achieved by comparing the required (demanded) current with the actual current to create a current error, which is then passed through a digital PI- type filter. The filtered current value is used to develop an output voltage for each motor coil. This method sets various constants and limits for the current feedback loop.

Parameters

chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • phase

  • kp_current

  • ki_current

  • i_lim_current

  • i_dead_band

  • kff

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_PMDJOYSTICKPARAMS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

The MJC001 joystick console has been designed for use by microscopists to provide intuitive, tactile, manual positioning of the stage. The console consists of a two axis joystick for XY control which features both low and high gear modes. This message is used to set max velocity and acceleration values for these modes.

Parameters

chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • js_gear_low_max_vel

  • js_gear_high_max_vel

  • js_gear_low_accn

  • js_gear_high_accn

  • dir_sense

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_PMDMOTOROUTPUTPARAMS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Used to set certain limits that can be applied to the motor drive signal.

Parameters

chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • cont_current_lim

  • energy_lim

  • motor_lim

  • motor_bias

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_PMDPOSITIONLOOPPARAMS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Used to set the position control loop parameters for the specified motor channel. The motion processors within the BBD series controllers use a position control loop to determine the motor command output. The purpose of the position loop is to match the actual motor position and the demanded position. This is achieved by comparing the demanded position with the actual encoder position to create a position error, which is then passed through a digital PID-type filter. The filtered value is the motor command output.

Parameters

chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • kp_pos

  • integral

  • i_lim_pos

  • differential

  • kd_time_pos

  • k_out_pos

  • k_vff_pos

  • k_aff_pos

  • pos_err_limit

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_PMDPROFILEMODEPARAMS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

The system incorporates a trajectory generator, which performs calculations to determine the instantaneous position, velocity and acceleration of each axis at any given moment. During a motion profile, these values will change continuously. Once the move is complete, these parameters will then remain unchanged until the next move begins. The specific move profile created by the system depends on several factors, such as the profile mode and profile parameters presently selected, and other conditions such as whether a motion stop has been requested. This method is used to set the profile mode to either ‘Trapezoidal’ or ‘S-curve’.

Parameters

chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • mode

  • jerk

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_PMDSETTLEDCURRENTLOOPPARAMS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

These commands assist in maintaining stable operation and reducing noise at the demanded position. They allow the system to be tuned such that errors caused by external vibration and manual handling (e.g. loading of samples) are minimized, and are applicable only when the stage is settled, i.e. the Axis Settled status bit (bit 14) is set.

Parameters

chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • phase

  • kp_settled

  • ki_settled

  • i_lim_settled

  • dead_band_set

  • kff_settled

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_PMDSTAGEAXISPARAMS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

The REQ and GET commands are used to obtain various parameters pertaining to the particular stage being driven. Most of these parameters are inherent in the design of the stage and cannot be altered. The SET command can only be used to increase the Minimum position value and decrease the Maximum position value, thereby reducing the overall travel of the stage.

Parameters

chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • stage_id

  • axis_id

  • part_no_axis

  • serial_num

  • cnts_per_unit

  • min_pos

  • max_pos

  • max_accn

  • max_dec

  • max_vel

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_PMDTRACKSETTLEPARAMS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Moves are generated by an internal profile generator, and are based on either a trapezoidal or S-curve trajectory. A move is considered complete when the profile generator has completed the calculated move and the axis has ‘settled’ at the demanded position. This command contains parameters which specify when the system is settled.

See page 81 for details.

Parameters

chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • time

  • settle_window

  • track_window

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_POSCOUNTER(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Used to set the ‘live’ position count in the controller. In general, this command is not normally used. Instead, the stage is homed immediately after power-up (at this stage the position is unknown as the stage is free to move when the power is off); and after the homing process is completed the position counter is automatically updated to show the actual position. From this point onwards the position counter always shows the actual absolute position.

Parameters

  • chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • position (int) – The new value of the position counter. Conversion should be done as in GenericStage.

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_POTPARAMS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

The potentiometer slider on the control panel panel is sprung, such that when released it returns to it’s central position. In this central position the motor is stationary. As the slider is moved away from the center, the motor begins to move; the speed of this movement increases as the slider deflection is increased. Bidirectional control of motor moves is possible by moving the slider in both directions. The speed of the motor increases by discrete amounts rather than continuously, as a function of slider deflection. These speed settings are defined by 4 pairs of parameters. Each pair specifies a pot deflection value (in the range 0 to 127) together with an associated velocity (set in encoder counts/sec) to be applied at or beyond that deflection. As each successive deflection is reached by moving the pot slider, the next velocity value is applied. These settings are applicable in either direction of pot deflection, i.e. 4 possible velocity settings in the forward or reverse motion directions. Note. The scaling factor between encoder counts and mm/sec depends on the specific stage/actuator being driven.

Parameters

chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • zero_wnd

  • vel1

  • wnd1

  • vel2

  • wnd2

  • vel3

  • wnd3

  • vel4

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_POWERPARAMS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

The power needed to hold a motor in a fixed position is much smaller than that required for a move. It is good practice to decrease the power in a stationary motor in order to reduce heating, and thereby minimize thermal movements caused by expansion. This message sets a reduction factor for the rest power and the move power values as a percentage of full power. Typically, move power should be set to 100% and rest power to a value significantly less than this.

Note for BSC20x, MST602 and TST101 controller users: If the controllers listed above are used with APTServer, the ini file will typically have values set of 5 for the rest power and 30 for the move power. Although these values are loaded when the server boots only the rest power value is used. This allows the user to set the rest current as normal. The move power however is not used. The move power is set within the controller as a function of velocity. This command can be used only to set the rest power. The command MGMSG_MOT_REQ_POWERPARAMS will return the default values or the values that were set.

Parameters

  • chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • rest_factor (int) – The phase power value when the motor is at rest, in the range 1 to 100 (i.e. 1% to 100% of full power).

  • move_factor (int) – The phase power value when the motor is moving, in the range 1 to 100 (i.e. 1% to 100% of full power).

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_TRIGGER(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

This message is used to configure the Motor controller for triggered move operation. It is possible to configure a particular controller to respond to trigger inputs, generate trigger outputs or both respond to and generate a trigger output. When a trigger input is received, the unit can be set to initiate a move (relative, absolute or home). Similarly the unit can be set to generate a trigger output signal when a specified event (e.g move initiated) occurs. For those units configured for both input and output triggering, a move can be initiated via a trigger input while at the same time, a trigger output can be generated to initiate a move on another unit. The trigger settings can be used to configure multiple units in a master – slave set up, thereby allowing multiple channels of motion to be synchronized. Multiple moves can then be initiated via a single software or hardware trigger command.

Parameters

chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • mode

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_TSTACTUATORTYPE(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

This command is for use only with the TST101 driver, and is used to define an actuator type so that the TST driver knows the effective length of the stage. This information is used if a user wishes to home the stage to the far travel end. In this case, once the stage is homed the APT GUI count will be set to the far travel value. For example, in the case of a ZFS25 the user will see 25mm once homed. The TST holds this value as a number of Trinamic microsteps, which will be a function of the gearbox ratio, the lead screw pitch, and the motor type. So for example the number stored in the TST for the ZFS25 is 54613333.

  • actuator_ident

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_VELPARAMS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Used to set the trapezoidal velocity parameters for the specified motor channel. For DC servo controllers, the velocity is set in encoder counts/sec and acceleration is set in encoder counts/sec/sec.

For stepper motor controllers the velocity is set in microsteps/sec and acceleration is set in microsteps/sec/sec.

Parameters

  • chan_ident (int) – channel number (0x01, 0x02)

  • min_velocity (int) – The minimum (start) velocity. Conversion should be done as in GenericStage.

  • acceleration (int) – The acceleration. Conversion should be done as in GenericStage.

  • max_velocity (int) – The maxium (final) velocity. Conversion should be done as in GenericStage.

class thorpy.message.motorcontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SUSPEND_ENDOFMOVEMSGS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Sent to disable all unsolicited end of move messages and error messages returned by the controller, i.e.

MGMSG_MOT_MOVE_STOPPED MGMSG_MOT_MOVE_COMPLETED MGMSG_MOT_MOVE_HOMED

The command also disables the error messages that the controller sends when an error conditions is detected:

MGMSG_HW_RESPONSE MGMSG_HW_RICHRESPONSE

class thorpy.message.filterflippercontrol.MGMSG_MOT_SET_MFF_OPERPARAMS(*args, source=1, dest=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Used to set various operating parameters that dictate the function of the MFF series flipper unit.
